comment._content: It might have something to do with weight. In those days you bought the chassis and the engine and then you went to a coach builder to have a coach fitted on it. The chassis builder indicated the amount of weight permissable.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02]  If they were staying in Castlebar. yes!... The 'bus' is heading out the Partry Road. W.L took lots of pictures of it around this time They weren't going too far otherwise... no coats..no baggage....Just a thought!!

comment.author: 54708393@N08
comment._content: Commercial Car Company Luton founded 1906 might help to date this. www.gracesguide.co.uk/File:Im090430Ox-1913CommerChara.jpg

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: This is the vehicle with a better view of CIE's "flying snail" logo! The vehicle is a Leyland Titan PD3/2 with a body built by CIE seating 74 passengers. It is listed as a "survivor" because it is preserved by a Mr Molloy of Dublin who aquired the vehicle in April 1982 after it had been withdrawn by CIE after 23 years service in Dublin. The livery it now wears is that worn by Dublin buses in the mid-1960's.
